message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and labs suggest eosinophilic asthma, which is often associated with p-ANCA levels. Proteinuria and hematuria may suggest glomerulonephritis, which can be associated with p-ANCA positivity. Smoking is a risk factor for asthma but is not directly associated with the patient’s most likely diagnosis. IgA deposits are associated with IgA nephropathy, which is not likely to be the cause of the patient’s proteinuria and hematuria. c-ANCA is associated with Wegener’s granulomatosis, which is not likely to be the cause of the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms (asthma, cough, smoking) and lab findings (elevated leukocyte count with eosinophils, proteinuria, and hematuria) suggest the diagnosis of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), formerly known as Churg-Strauss syndrome. p-ANCA positivity is common in EGPA, while c-ANCA levels and IgA deposits are more commonly associated with other vasculitides. Smoking is a risk factor for many respiratory conditions, including asthma, but it is not specifically associated with EGPA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including worsening asthma symptoms and cough, increased smoking, and labs showing elevated leukocyte count with eosinophils and proteinuria with hematuria suggest the most likely diagnosis is eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). The presence of p-ANCA antibodies is associated with EGPA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, specifically the presence of asthma and eosinophilia, suggest a diagnosis of allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), a complication of asthma caused by hypersensitivity to Aspergillus fumigatus. P-ANCA levels are associated with ABPA, while c-ANCA and IgA deposits are associated with other conditions. Smoking is a risk factor for many respiratory conditions, but it is not specifically associated with ABPA. The presence of proteinuria and microscopic hematuria suggests renal involvement, which can occur in ABPA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history, symptoms, and laboratory findings suggest that he may have eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), previously known as Churg-Strauss syndrome. p-ANCA levels are associated with this condition. c-ANCA levels are associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), previously known as Wegener’s granulomatosis, which presents with different symptoms such as sinus and pulmonary involvement. IgA deposits are associated with IgA nephropathy, which may present with proteinuria and microscopic hematuria, but does not typically present with respiratory symptoms or asthma. Smoking is a risk factor for many respiratory conditions, but is not specifically associated with EGPA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, labs, and history of smoking suggest a diagnosis of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), formerly known as Churg-Strauss syndrome. p-ANCA levels are typically elevated in EGPA. c-ANCA levels are more typically seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener’s granulomatosis). IgA deposits are associated with IgA vasculitis (formerly known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura), which typically presents with abdominal pain and cutaneous purpura. Smoking is associated with many respiratory and vascular diseases, but is not specifically associated with EGPA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including worsening asthma and cough, along with labs showing eosinophilia and proteinuria with hematuria, suggest the diagnosis of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), also known as Churg-Strauss Syndrome. p-ANCA levels are associated with this condition, whereas c-ANCA levels and IgA deposits are associated with other vasculitides. Smoking may worsen the patient’s symptoms, but it is not associated with the diagnosis of EGPA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest asthma exacerbation, and the labs show eosinophilia and proteinuria with hematuria, which are indicative of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). EGPA is also associated with elevated p-ANCA levels. Smoking is a risk factor for asthma exacerbation but is not specifically associated with EGPA. c-ANCA levels and IgA deposits are associated with other types of vasculitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with worsening asthma symptoms and a smoking history, which can suggest a diagnosis of eosinophilic asthma or Churg-Strauss syndrome. The presence of proteinuria and microscopic hematuria suggests renal involvement, which is a feature of Churg-Strauss syndrome. p-ANCA levels are associated with this condition. c-ANCA levels are associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's), while IgA deposits are associated with IgA nephropathy. Smoking is a risk factor for many conditions but is not directly associated with the patient's most likely diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible diagnosis of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), previously known as Churg-Strauss syndrome, which is an ANCA-associated vasculitis. The presence of eosinophils and proteinuria on urinalysis can support this diagnosis. Among the options, only p-ANCA levels are associated with EGPA. Smoking is a risk factor for developing ANCA-associated vasculitis, but it is not specific to EGPA.
